text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth. Patient: Well I guess... Family Member: How long would we have to do that for that just out of curiosity? Doctor: It’s a, I’ll give you the exact… Doctor: Yeah but it’s more for the monitoring and because it’s a phase one trial it’s a little bit more closer monitoring. At least the first few weeks. After that it goes down to once a month once we sort of get the comfort level that you’re tolerating it okay, we know all the PKs and the blood level things are done, then it becomes much easier schedule. Family Member: What are the, how often are you talking about? A couple times a week or? Doctor: Well the first few weeks it will be about once a week or so or once every couple of weeks after a little while. And then after the first couple of months it goes to like I said once every four weeks.

text: Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. You may say that we don’t have a prescription plan or it’s too expensive, and I can’t do it for that reason. It may be that we get through that and the door’s still open for the study because you can afford it and we can get started. Okay? But you guys have to talk about it as a family. You’ve got the paperwork to read. You can go through it, discuss it. You know, okay, this would mean that we’re gonna have to commit to going down to Baltimore every other week this time, do some more bloodwork. These are the things that I worry about. Yeah, we’re all good for that. Okay? Because you’re not on the study until you meet again with us, that your PSA is rising on the enzalutamide Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have to get the enzalutamide started (Pause) Patient: Okay. Okay. Lemme just, so the enzalutamide, the Xtandi, okay. Doctor: That’s all we’re going to start now, and you have to get worse on it to be able to be eligible for the study. (Pause15sec) Patient: Well. We would start first with the Xtandi. I have to – the disease has to progress some more – Doctor: Uh, by PSA only. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I don’t think you’re gonna need new scans, but that maybe sort of something down the road, but I think you, you really just have to have a rising PSA on the enzalutamide, and then we have to repeat that ARV seven. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
